member.name: P:MimeKit.Cryptography.BouncyCastleSecureMimeContext.CheckCertificateRevocation
member.summary: Get or set whether or not certificate revocation should be checked when verifying signatures.

remarks.para: Gets or sets whether or not certificate revocation should be checked when verifying signatures.
If enabled, the will attempt to automatically download Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs) from the internet based on the CRL Distribution Point extension on each certificate.

member.value: true if certificate revocation should be checked; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Get the X.509 certificate matching the specified selector.

This method is used when constructing a certificate chain if the S/MIME signature does not include a signer's certificate.

member.returns: The certificate on success; otherwise null.
member.param: The search criteria for the certificate.

remarks.para: A trusted anchor is a trusted root-level X.509 certificate, generally issued by a certificate authority (CA).
This method is used to build a certificate chain while verifying signed content.
An intermediate certificate is any certificate that exists between the root certificate issued by a Certificate Authority (CA) and the certificate at the end of the chain.
This method is used to build a certificate chain while verifying signed content.

The signature protocol is used by in order to determine what the protocol parameter of the Content-Type header should be.

The key exchange protocol is really only used for OpenPGP.

member.summary: The default database path for certificates, private keys and CRLs.

remarks.para: On Microsoft Windows-based systems, this path will be something like C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Roaming\mimekit\smime.db.
On Unix systems such as Linux and Mac OS X, this path will be ~/.mimekit/smime.db.

remarks.para: Digest algorithms are secure hashing algorithms that are used to generate unique fixed-length signatures for arbitrary data.

The most commonly used digest algorithms are currently MD5 and SHA-1, however, MD5 was successfully broken in 2008 and should be avoided. In late 2013, Microsoft announced that they would be retiring their use of SHA-1 in their products by 2016 with the assumption that its days as an unbroken digest algorithm were numbered. It is speculated that the SHA-1 digest algorithm will be vulnerable to collisions, and thus no longer considered secure, by 2018.
Microsoft and other vendors plan to move to the SHA-2 suite of digest algorithms which includes the following 4 variants: SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512.

When verifying a digitally signed MIME part such as a or a , you will get back a collection of digital signatures. Typically, a signed message will only have a single signature (created by the sender of the message), but it is possible for there to be multiple signatures.

remarks.para: Empirical evidence demonstrates that some mail servers and relay systems modify email in transit, potentially invalidating a signature. There are two competing perspectives on such modifications. For most signers, mild modification of email is immaterial to the authentication status of the email. For such signers, a canonicalization algorithm that survives modest in-transit modification is preferred.

Other signers demand that any modification of the email, however minor, result in a signature verification failure. These signers prefer a canonicalization algorithm that does not tolerate in-transit modification of the signed email.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.DkimCanonicalizationAlgorithm.Simple
member.summary: The simple canonicalization algorithm tolerates almost no modification by mail servers while the message is in-transit.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.DkimCanonicalizationAlgorithm.Relaxed
member.summary: The relaxed canonicalization algorithm tolerates common modifications by mail servers while the message is in-transit such as whitespace replacement and header field line rewrapping.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Cryptography.EncryptionAlgorithm
member.summary: Encryption algorithms supported by S/MIME and OpenPGP.

remarks.para: Represents the available encryption algorithms for use with S/MIME and OpenPGP.

RC-2/40 was required by all S/MIME v2 implementations. However, since the mid-to-late 1990's, RC-2/40 has been considered to be extremely weak and starting with S/MIME v3.0 (published in 1999), all S/MIME implementations are required to implement support for Triple-DES (aka 3DES) and should no longer encrypt using RC-2/40 unless explicitly requested to do so by the user.

These days, most S/MIME implementations support the AES-128 and AES-256 algorithms which are the recommended algorithms specified in S/MIME v3.2 and should be preferred over the use of Triple-DES unless the client capabilities of one or more of the recipients is unknown (or only supports Triple-DES).

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.EncryptionAlgorithm.Des
member.remarks: This is extremely weak encryption and should not be used without consent from the user.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.EncryptionAlgorithm.TripleDes
member.remarks: This is the weakest recommended encryption algorithm for use starting with S/MIME v3 and should only be used as a fallback if it is unknown what encryption algorithms are supported by the recipient's mail client.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.EncryptionAlgorithm.RC240
member.remarks: This is extremely weak encryption and should not be used without consent from the user.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.EncryptionAlgorithm.RC264
member.remarks: This is very weak encryption and should not be used without consent from the user.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Cryptography.NpgsqlCertificateDatabase

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.OpenPgpKeyCertification.PositiveCertification

member.name: T:MimeKit.Cryptography.SecureMailboxAddress
member.summary: A secure mailbox address which includes a fingerprint for a certificate.

remarks.para: When signing or encrypting a message, it is necessary to look up the X.509 certificate in order to do the actual sign or encrypt operation. One way of accomplishing this is to use the email address of sender or recipient as a unique identifier. However, a better approach is to use the fingerprint (or 'thumbprint' in Microsoft parlance) of the user's certificate.

remarks.para: The X.509 Key Usage Flags can be used to determine what operations a certificate can be used for.

para.alert: A value of indicates that there are no restrictions on the use of the .

member.summary: No limitations for the key usage are set.
member.remarks: The key may be used for anything.

member.summary: The key may only be used for enciphering data during key agreement.
member.remarks: When both the bit and the bit are both set, the key may be used only for enciphering data while performing key agreement.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.CrlSign
member.summary: The key may be used for verifying signatures on certificate revocation lists (CRLs).

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.KeyCertSign
member.summary: The key may be used for verifying signatures on certificates.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.KeyAgreement
member.summary: The key is meant to be used for key agreement.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.DataEncipherment
member.summary: The key may be used for data encipherment.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.KeyEncipherment
member.summary: The key is meant to be used for key encipherment.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.NonRepudiation
member.summary: The key may be used to verify digital signatures used to provide a non-repudiation service.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.DigitalSignature
member.summary: The key may be used for digitally signing data.

member.name: F:MimeKit.Cryptography.X509KeyUsageFlags.DecipherOnly
member.summary: The key may only be used for deciphering data during key agreement.
member.remarks: When both the bit and the bit are both set, the key may be used only for deciphering data while performing key agreement.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Encodings.UUDecoder
member.summary: Incrementally decodes content encoded with the Unix-to-Unix encoding.

remarks.para: The UUEncoding is an encoding that predates MIME and was used to encode binary content such as images and other types of multi-media to ensure that the data remained intact when sent via 7bit transports such as SMTP.
These days, the UUEncoding has largely been deprecated in favour of the base64 encoding, however, some older mail clients still use it.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.BoundStream
member.summary: A bounded stream, confined to reading and writing data to a limited subset of the overall source stream.

remarks.para: Wraps an arbitrary stream, limiting I/O operations to a subset of the source stream. If the is -1, then the end of the stream is unbound.
When a is set to parse a persistent stream, it will construct s using bounded streams instead of loading the content into memory.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.ICancellableStream
member.summary: An interface allowing for a cancellable stream reading operation.

remarks.para: This interface is meant to extend the functionality of a , allowing the to have much finer-grained canellability.
When a custom stream implementation also implements this interface, the will opt to use this interface instead of the normal API to read data from the stream.
This is really useful when parsing a message or other MIME entity directly from a network-based stream.

member.name: M:MimeKit.IO.ICancellableStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.

remarks.para: When a custom stream implementation also implements this interface, the will opt to use this interface instead of the normal API to read data from the stream.
This is really useful when parsing a message or other MIME entity directly from a network-based stream.

member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero (0) if the end of the stream has been reached.
member.param: The buffer to read data into.
The offset into the buffer to start reading data.
The number of bytes to read.

member.name: M:MimeKit.IO.ICancellableStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Writes a sequence of bytes to the stream and advances the current position within this stream by the number of bytes written.

remarks.para: When a custom stream implementation also implements this interface, writing a or to the custom stream will opt to use this interface instead of the normal API to write data to the stream.
This is really useful when writing a message or other MIME entity directly to a network-based stream.

member.param: The offset of the first byte to write.
The number of bytes to write.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.MemoryBlockStream
member.summary: An efficient memory stream implementation that sacrifices the ability to get access to the internal byte buffer in order to drastically improve performance.
member.remarks: Instead of resizing an internal byte array, the chains blocks of non-contiguous memory. This helps improve performance by avoiding unneeded copying of data from the old array to the newly allocated array as well as the zeroing of the newly allocated array.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: Creates a new with an initial memory block of 2048 bytes.

member.summary: Copies the memory stream into a byte array.
member.remarks: Copies all of the stream data into a newly allocated byte array.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.Filters.ArmoredFromFilter
member.summary: A filter that armors lines beginning with "From " by encoding the 'F' with the Quoted-Printable encoding.

remarks.para: From-armoring is a workaround to prevent receiving clients (or servers) that uses the mbox file format for local storage from munging the line by prepending a ">", as is typical with the mbox format.
This armoring technique ensures that the receiving client will still be able to verify S/MIME signatures.

member.remarks: Resets the filter.

member.name: P:MimeKit.Text.FlowedToHtml.DeleteSpace
member.summary: Get or set whether the trailing space on a wrapped line should be deleted.

remarks.para: Gets or sets whether the trailing space on a wrapped line should be deleted.

The flowed text format defines a Content-Type parameter called "delsp" which can have a value of "yes" or "no". If the parameter exists and the value is "yes", then should be set to true, otherwise should be set to false.

member.value: true if the trailing space on a wrapped line should be deleted; otherwise, false.

member.remarks: TNEF data often contains properties that map to headers. TNEF data also often contains file attachments which will be mapped to MIME parts.
member.returns: A message representing the TNEF data in MIME format.

member.name: M:MimeKit.Tnef.TnefPart.ExtractAttachments
member.summary: Extracts the embedded attachments from the TNEF data.
member.remarks: Parses the TNEF data and extracts all of the embedded file attachments.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeParser.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MimeKit.MimeFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: Creates a new that will parse the specified stream.

If is true and is seekable, then the will not copy the content of s into memory. Instead, it will use a to reference a substream of . This has the potential to not only save memory usage, but also improve performance.
It should be noted, however, that disposing will make it impossible for to read the content.

member.param: true if the stream is persistent; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MimeKit.ContentDisposition
member.summary: A class representing a Content-Disposition header value.
member.remarks: The Content-Disposition header is a way for the originating client to suggest to the receiving client whether to present the part to the user as an attachment or as part of the content (inline).

member.remarks: Indicates that the should be treated as an attachment.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.FormData
member.remarks: Indicates that the should be treated as form data.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.Inline
member.remarks: Indicates that the should be rendered inline.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: This is identical to with a disposition value of .

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.Disposition
member.remarks: The disposition is typically either "attachment" or "inline".

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the is an attachment.
member.remarks: A convenience property to determine if the entity should be considered an attachment or not.
member.value: true if the is an attachment; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.Parameters
member.remarks: In addition to specifying whether the entity should be treated as an attachment vs displayed inline, the Content-Disposition header may also contain parameters to provide further information to the receiving client such as the file attributes.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.FileName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the file.
member.remarks: When set, this can provide a useful hint for a default file name for the content when the user decides to save it to disk.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.CreationDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the creation-date parameter.
member.remarks: Refers to the date and time that the content file was created on the originating system. This parameter serves little purpose and is typically not used by mail clients.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.ModificationDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the modification-date parameter.
member.remarks: Refers to the date and time that the content file was last modified on the originating system. This parameter serves little purpose and is typically not used by mail clients.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.ReadDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the read-date parameter.
member.remarks: Refers to the date and time that the content file was last read on the originating system. This parameter serves little purpose and is typically not used by mail clients.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size parameter.
member.remarks: When set, the size parameter typically refers to the original size of the content on disk. This parameter is rarely used by mail clients as it serves little purpose.

member.name: T:MimeKit.ContentEncoding
member.summary: An enumeration of all supported content transfer encodings. .
member.remarks: Some older mail software is unable to properly deal with data outside of the ASCII range, so it is sometimes necessary to encode the content of MIME entities.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Default
member.summary: The default encoding (aka no encoding at all).

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.SevenBit
member.remarks: This encoding should be restricted to textual content in the US-ASCII range.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.EightBit
member.remarks: This encoding should be restricted to textual content outside of the US-ASCII range but may not be supported by all transport services such as older SMTP servers that do not support the 8BITMIME extension.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Binary
member.remarks: This encoding is simply unencoded binary data. Typically not supported by standard message transport services such as SMTP.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Base64
member.remarks: This encoding is typically used for encoding binary data or textual content in a largely 8bit charset encoding and is supported by all message transport services.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.QuotedPrintable
member.summary: The quoted printable content transfer encoding. .
member.remarks: This encoding is used for textual content that is in a charset that has a minority of characters outside of the US-ASCII range (such as ISO-8859-1 and other single-byte charset encodings) and is supported by all message transport services.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.UUEncode
member.remarks: This is an obsolete encoding meant for encoding binary data and has largely been superceeded by .

member.name: T:MimeKit.ContentType
member.summary: A class representing a Content-Type header value.
member.remarks: The Content-Type header is a way for the originating client to suggest to the receiving client the mime-type of the content and, depending on that mime-type, presentation options such as charset.

member.name: M:MimeKit.ContentType.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: Creates a new based on the media type and subtype provided.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.MediaType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of the media.
member.remarks: Represents the media type of the . Examples include "text", "image", and "application". This string should always be treated as case-insensitive.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.MediaSubtype
member.summary: Gets or sets the media subtype.
member.remarks: Represents the media subtype of the . Examples include "html", "jpeg", and "octet-stream". This string should always be treated as case-insensitive.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.Parameters
member.remarks: In addition to the media type and subtype, the Content-Type header may also contain parameters to provide further hints to the receiving client as to how to process or display the content.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.Boundary
member.summary: Gets or sets the boundary parameter.
member.remarks: This is a special parameter on entities, designating to the parser a unique string that should be considered the boundary marker for each sub-part.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.Charset
member.summary: Gets or sets the charset parameter.
member.remarks: Text-based entities will often include a charset parameter so that the receiving client can properly render the text.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.Format
member.summary: Gets or sets the format parameter.
member.remarks: The format parameter is typically use with text/plain entities and will either have a value of "fixed" or "flowed".

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.MimeType
member.remarks: Gets the simple mime-type.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentType.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name parameter.
member.remarks: The name parameter is a way for the originiating client to suggest to the receiving client a display-name for the content, which may be used by the receiving client if it cannot display the actual content to the user.

member.name: M:MimeKit.ContentType.IsMimeType(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the this instance of matches the specified MIME media type and subtype.
member.remarks: If the specified or are "*", they match anything.
member.returns: true if the matches the provided media type and subtype.

member.name: T:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint
member.remarks: Not all message transports support binary or 8-bit data, so it becomes necessary to constrain the content encoding to a subset of the possible Content-Transfer-Encoding values.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.None
member.summary: There are no encoding constraints, the content may contain any byte.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.EightBit
member.summary: The content may contain bytes with the high bit set, but must not contain any zero-bytes.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.SevenBit
member.summary: The content may only contain bytes within the 7-bit ASCII range.

member.name: T:MimeKit.NewLineFormat
member.remarks: There are two commonly used line-endings used by modern Operating Systems. Unix-based systems such as Linux and Mac OS use a single character ('\n' aka LF) to represent the end of line where-as Windows (or DOS) uses a sequence of two characters ("\r\n" aka CRLF). Most text-based network protocols such as SMTP, POP3, and IMAP use the CRLF sequence as well.

member.name: T:MimeKit.FormatOptions
member.summary: Format options for serializing various MimeKit objects.
member.remarks: Represents the available options for formatting MIME messages and entities when writing them to a stream.

member.name: F:MimeKit.FormatOptions.Default
member.remarks: If a custom is not passed to methods such as , the default options will be used.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.MaxLineLength
member.summary: Gets the maximum line length used by the encoders. The encoders use this value to determine where to place line breaks.
member.remarks: Specifies the maximum line length to use when line-wrapping headers.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.NewLineFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the new-line format.
member.remarks: Specifies the new-line encoding to use when writing the message or entity to a stream.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.HiddenHeaders
member.summary: Gets the message headers that should be hidden.

remarks.para: Specifies the set of headers that should be removed when writing a to a stream.
This is primarily meant for the purposes of removing Bcc and Resent-Bcc headers when sending via a transport such as SMTP.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.International
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the new "Internationalized Email" formatting standards should be used.

remarks.para: The new "Internationalized Email" format is defined by rfc6530 and rfc6532.
This feature should only be used when formatting messages meant to be sent via SMTP using the SMTPUTF8 extension (rfc6531) or when appending messages to an IMAP folder via UTF8 APPEND (rfc6855).

member.value: true if the new internationalized formatting should be used; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.AllowMixedHeaderCharsets
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the formatter should allow mixed charsets in the headers.

remarks.para: When this option is enabled, the MIME formatter will try to use US-ASCII and/or ISO-8859-1 to encode headers when appropriate rather than being forced to use the specified charset for all encoded-word tokens in order to maximize readability.

Unfortunately, mail clients like Outlook and Thunderbird do not treat encoded-word tokens individually and assume that all tokens are encoded using the charset declared in the first encoded-word token despite the specification explicitly stating that each encoded-word token should be treated independently.

The Thunderbird bug can be tracked at
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=317263.

member.value: true if the formatter should be allowed to use ISO-8859-1 when encoding headers; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.FormatOptions.ParameterEncodingMethod
member.summary: The method to use for encoding Content-Type and Content-Disposition parameter values.

remarks.para: The method to use for encoding Content-Type and Content-Disposition parameter values when the is set to .

The MIME specifications specify that the proper method for encoding Content-Type and Content-Disposition parameter values is the method described in rfc2231. However, it is common for some older email clients to improperly encode using the method described in rfc2047 instead.

member.value: The parameter encoding method that will be used.

member.remarks: Creates a new set of formatting options for use with methods such as .

member.remarks: Clones the formatting options.

member.summary: Get the default formatting options in a thread-safe way.
member.remarks: Gets the default formatting options in a thread-safe way.

member.name: M:MimeKit.Header.GetValue(System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Gets the header value using the specified character encoding.

remarks.para: If the raw header value does not properly encode non-ASCII text, the decoder will fall back to a default charset encoding. Sometimes, however, this default charset fallback is wrong and the mail client may wish to override that default charset on a per-header basis.
By using this method, the client is able to override the fallback charset on a per-header basis.

member.param: The character encoding to use as a fallback.

member.name: M:MimeKit.Header.GetValue(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the header value using the specified charset.

remarks.para: If the raw header value does not properly encode non-ASCII text, the decoder will fall back to a default charset encoding. Sometimes, however, this default charset fallback is wrong and the mail client may wish to override that default charset on a per-header basis.
By using this method, the client is able to override the fallback charset on a per-header basis.

member.param: The charset to use as a fallback.

member.name: T:MimeKit.InternetAddress
member.summary: An internet address, as specified by rfc0822.

remarks.para: A can be any type of address defined by the original Internet Message specification.
There are effectively two (2) types of addresses: mailboxes and groups.
Mailbox addresses are what are most commonly known as email addresses and are represented by the class.

Group addresses are themselves lists of addresses and are represented by the class. While rare, it is still important to handle these types of addresses. They typically only contain mailbox addresses, but may also contain other group addresses.

member.name: T:MimeKit.MessageDeliveryStatus
member.summary: A message delivery status MIME part.

remarks.para: A message delivery status MIME part is a machine readable notification denoting the delivery status of a message and has a MIME-type of message/delivery-status.
For more information, see rfc3464.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: Creates a new .

member.name: P:MimeKit.MessageDeliveryStatus.StatusGroups
member.summary: Get the groups of delivery status fields.

remarks.para: Gets the groups of delivery status fields. The first contains the per-message fields while each remaining contains fields that pertain to particular recipients of the message.
For more information about these fields and their values, check out rfc3464.
Section 2.2 defines the per-message fields while Section 2.3 defines the per-recipient fields.

member.name: T:MimeKit.MessagePartial
member.summary: A MIME part containing a partial message as its content.

remarks.para: The "message/partial" MIME-type is used to split large messages into multiple parts, typically to work around transport systems that have size limitations (for example, some SMTP servers limit have a maximum message size that they will accept).

member.name: M:MimeKit.MessagePartial.#ctor(MimeKit.MimeEntityConstructorArgs)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by .

member.name: M:MimeKit.MessagePartial.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: Creates a new message/partial entity.
Three (3) parameters must be specified in the Content-Type header of a message/partial: id, number, and total.
The "id" parameter is a unique identifier used to match the parts together.
The "number" parameter is the sequential (1-based) index of the partial message fragment.
The "total" parameter is the total number of pieces that make up the complete message.

member.param: The id value shared among the partial message parts.
The (1-based) part number for this partial message part.
The total number of partial message parts.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MessagePartial.Id
member.summary: Gets the "id" parameter of the Content-Type header.
member.remarks: The "id" parameter is a unique identifier used to match the parts together.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MessagePartial.Number
member.summary: Gets the "number" parameter of the Content-Type header.
member.remarks: The "number" parameter is the sequential (1-based) index of the partial message fragment.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MessagePartial.Total
member.summary: Gets the "total" parameter of the Content-Type header.
member.remarks: The "total" parameter is the total number of pieces that make up the complete message.

remarks.para: A MIME entity is really just a node in a tree structure of MIME parts in a MIME message.
There are 3 basic types of entities: , , and (which is actually just a special variation of who's content is another MIME message/document). All other types are derivatives of one of those.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.Headers
member.remarks: Represents the list of headers for a MIME part. Typically, the headers of a MIME part will be various Content-* headers such as Content-Type or Content-Disposition, but may include just about anything.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentDisposition
member.summary: Gets or sets the content disposition.
member.remarks: Represents the pre-parsed Content-Disposition header value, if present. If the Content-Disposition header is not set, then this property will be null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentType
member.summary: Gets the type of the content.

remarks.para: The Content-Type header specifies information about the type of content contained within the MIME entity.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentBase
member.summary: Gets or sets the base content URI.

remarks.para: The Content-Base header specifies the base URI for the in cases where the is a relative URI.
The Content-Base URI must be an absolute URI.
For more information, see rfc2110.

member.value: The base content URI or null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the content location.

remarks.para: The Content-Location header specifies the URI for a MIME entity and can be either absolute or relative.

Setting a Content-Location URI allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by URI. This can be useful, for example, when constructing an HTML message body that needs to reference image attachments.
For more information, see rfc2110.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentId
member.summary: Gets or sets the content identifier.

remarks.para: The Content-Id header is used for uniquely identifying a particular entity and uses the same syntax as the Message-Id header on MIME messages.

Setting a Content-Id allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by its unique identifier, typically by using a "cid:" URI in an HTML-formatted message body. This can be useful, for example, when the HTML-formatted message body needs to reference image attachments.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.IsAttachment
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this is an attachment.
member.remarks: If the Content-Disposition header is set and has a value of "attachment", then this property returns true. Otherwise it is assumed that the is not meant to be treated as an attachment.
member.value: true if this is an attachment; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeIterator.Parent
member.summary: Gets the parent of the current entity.

remarks.para: After an iterator is created or after the method is called, the method must be called to advance the iterator to the first entity of the message before reading the value of the Parent property; otherwise, Parent throws a . Parent also throws a if the last call to returned false, which indicates the end of the message.
If the current entity is the top-level entity of the message, then the parent will be null; otherwise the parent will be either be a or a .

member.exception: Either has not been called or has moved beyond the end of the message.

Current also throws a if the last call to returned false, which indicates the end of the message.
member.exception: Either has not been called or has moved beyond the end of the message.

member.summary: Gets the path specifier for the current entity.
member.remarks: After an iterator is created or after the method is called, the method must be called to advance the iterator to the first entity of the message before reading the value of the PathSpecifier property; otherwise, PathSpecifier throws a . PathSpecifier also throws a if the last call to returned false, which indicates the end of the message.
member.exception: Either has not been called or has moved beyond the end of the message.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeIterator.Depth
member.summary: Gets the depth of the current entity.
member.remarks: After an iterator is created or after the method is called, the method must be called to advance the iterator to the first entity of the message before reading the value of the Depth property; otherwise, Depth throws a . Depth also throws a if the last call to returned false, which indicates the end of the message.
member.exception: Either has not been called or has moved beyond the end of the message.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeIterator.MoveNext
member.summary: Advances the iterator to the next depth-first entity of the tree structure.
member.remarks: After an iterator is created or after the method is called, an iterator is positioned before the first entity of the message, and the first call to the MoveNext method moves the iterator to the first entity of the message. If MoveNext advances beyond the last entity of the message, MoveNext returns false. When the iterator is at this position, subsequent calls to MoveNext also return false until is called.
member.returns: true if the iterator was successfully advanced to the next entity; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeIterator.MoveTo(System.String)
member.summary: Advances to the entity specified by the path specifier.

remarks.para: Advances the iterator to the entity specified by the path specifier which must be in the same format as returned by .
If the iterator has already advanced beyond the entity at the specified path, the iterator will and advance as normal.

member.returns: true if advancing to the specified entity was successful; otherwise, false.

member.remarks: Resets the iterator to its initial state.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeIterator.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by the object.
member.remarks: Call when you are finished using the . The method leaves the in an unusable state. After calling , you must release all references to the so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the was occupying.

remarks.para: A message consists of header fields and, optionally, a body.
The body of the message can either be plain text or it can be a tree of MIME entities such as a text/plain MIME part and a collection of file attachments.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.MboxMarker
member.summary: Gets or sets the mbox marker.
member.remarks: Set by the when parsing attached message/rfc822 parts so that the message/rfc822 part can be reserialized back to its original form.

remarks.para: Represents the list of headers for a message. Typically, the headers of a message will contain transmission headers such as From and To along with metadata headers such as Subject and Date, but may include just about anything.

para.alert: To access any MIME headers other than , you will need to access the property of the .

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Importance
member.summary: Get or set the value of the Importance header.
member.remarks: Gets or sets the value of the Importance header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Priority
member.summary: Get or set the value of the Priority header.
member.remarks: Gets or sets the value of the Priority header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.XPriority
member.summary: Get or set the value of the X-Priority header.
member.remarks: Gets or sets the value of the X-Priority header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Sender
member.summary: Gets or sets the address in the Sender header.
member.remarks: The sender may differ from the addresses in if the message was sent by someone on behalf of someone else.
member.value: The address in the Sender header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentSender
member.summary: Gets or sets the address in the Resent-Sender header.
member.remarks: The resent sender may differ from the addresses in if the message was sent by someone on behalf of someone else.
member.value: The address in the Resent-Sender header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.From
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the From header.

remarks.para: The "From" header specifies the author(s) of the message.
If more than one is added to the list of "From" addresses, the should be set to the single of the personal actually sending the message.

member.value: The list of addresses in the From header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentFrom
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Resent-From header.

remarks.para: The "Resent-From" header specifies the author(s) of the messagebeing resent.
If more than one is added to the list of "Resent-From" addresses, the should be set to the single of the personal actually sending the message.

member.value: The list of addresses in the Resent-From header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ReplyTo
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Reply-To header.

remarks.para: When the list of addresses in the Reply-To header is not empty, it contains the address(es) where the author(s) of the message prefer that replies be sent.
When the list of addresses in the Reply-To header is empty, replies should be sent to the mailbox(es) specified in the From header.

member.value: The list of addresses in the Reply-To header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentReplyTo
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Resent-Reply-To header.

remarks.para: When the list of addresses in the Resent-Reply-To header is not empty, it contains the address(es) where the author(s) of the resent message prefer that replies be sent.
When the list of addresses in the Resent-Reply-To header is empty, replies should be sent to the mailbox(es) specified in the Resent-From header.

member.value: The list of addresses in the Resent-Reply-To header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.To
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the To header.
member.remarks: The addresses in the To header are the primary recipients of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the To header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentTo
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Resent-To header.
member.remarks: The addresses in the Resent-To header are the primary recipients of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the Resent-To header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Cc
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Cc header.
member.remarks: The addresses in the Cc header are secondary recipients of the message and are usually not the individuals being directly addressed in the content of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the Cc header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentCc
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Resent-Cc header.
member.remarks: The addresses in the Resent-Cc header are secondary recipients of the message and are usually not the individuals being directly addressed in the content of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the Resent-Cc header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Bcc
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Bcc header.
member.remarks: Recipients in the Blind-Carpbon-Copy list will not be visible to the other recipients of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the Bcc header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentBcc
member.summary: Gets the list of addresses in the Resent-Bcc header.
member.remarks: Recipients in the Resent-Bcc list will not be visible to the other recipients of the message.
member.value: The list of addresses in the Resent-Bcc header.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Subject
member.summary: Gets or sets the subject of the message.

remarks.para: The Subject is typically a short string denoting the topic of the message.
Replies will often use "Re: " followed by the Subject of the original message.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Date
member.summary: Gets or sets the date of the message.
member.remarks: If the date is not explicitly set before the message is written to a stream, the date will default to the exact moment when it is written to said stream.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.ResentDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the Resent-Date of the message.
member.remarks: Gets or sets the Resent-Date of the message.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.References
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of references to other messages.
member.remarks: The References header contains a chain of Message-Ids back to the original message that started the thread.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.InReplyTo
member.summary: Gets or sets the Message-Id that this message is in reply to.
member.remarks: If the message is a reply to another message, it will typically use the In-Reply-To header to specify the Message-Id of the original message being replied to.
member.value: The message id that this message is in reply to.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets the message identifier.

can be used to generate this value.

can be used to generate this value.

member.remarks: The MIME-Version header specifies the version of the MIME specification that the message was created for.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Body
member.summary: Gets or sets the body of the message.

remarks.para: The body of the message can either be plain text or it can be a tree of MIME entities such as a text/plain MIME part and a collection of file attachments.
For a convenient way of constructing message bodies, see the class.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.TextBody
member.summary: Gets the text body of the message if it exists.

remarks.para: Gets the text content of the first text/plain body part that is found (in depth-first search order) which is not an attachment.

member.value: The text body if it exists; otherwise, null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.HtmlBody
member.summary: Gets the html body of the message if it exists.

remarks.para: Gets the HTML-formatted body of the message if it exists.

member.value: The html body if it exists; otherwise, null.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.GetTextBody(MimeKit.Text.TextFormat)
member.summary: Gets the text body in the specified format.
member.remarks: Gets the text body in the specified format, if it exists.
member.returns: The text body in the desired format if it exists; otherwise, null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.BodyParts
member.summary: Gets the body parts of the message.
member.remarks: Traverses over the MIME tree, enumerating all of the objects, but does not traverse into the bodies of attached messages.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Attachments
member.remarks: Traverses over the MIME tree, enumerating all of the objects that have a Content-Disposition header set to "attachment".

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Sign(MimeKit.Cryptography.CryptographyContext,MimeKit.Cryptography.DigestAlgorithm)
member.summary: Sign the message using the specified cryptography context and digest algorithm.
member.remarks: If either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be signed using the Resent-Sender (or first mailbox in the Resent-From) address as the signer address, otherwise the Sender or From address will be used instead.

exception.para: A sender has not been specified.

member.exception: A signing certificate could not be found for the sender.
The private key could not be found for the sender.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Sign(MimeKit.Cryptography.CryptographyContext)
member.summary: Sign the message using the specified cryptography context and the SHA-1 digest algorithm.
member.remarks: If either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be signed using the Resent-Sender (or first mailbox in the Resent-From) address as the signer address, otherwise the Sender or From address will be used instead.

exception.para: A sender has not been specified.

member.exception: A signing certificate could not be found for the sender.
The private key could not be found for the sender.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.Encrypt(MimeKit.Cryptography.CryptographyContext)
member.summary: Encrypt the message to the sender and all of the recipients using the specified cryptography context.
member.remarks: If either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the Resent headers (Resent-Sender, Resent-From, Resent-To, Resent-Cc, and Resent-Bcc), otherwise the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the standard address headers (Sender, From, To, Cc, and Bcc).
member.exception: An unknown type of cryptography context was used.
A certificate could not be found for one or more of the recipients.
The public key could not be found for one or more of the recipients.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.SignAndEncrypt(MimeKit.Cryptography.CryptographyContext,MimeKit.Cryptography.DigestAlgorithm)
member.summary: Sign and encrypt the message to the sender and all of the recipients using the specified cryptography context and the specified digest algorithm.

remarks.para: If either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be signed using the Resent-Sender (or first mailbox in the Resent-From) address as the signer address, otherwise the Sender or From address will be used instead.

Likewise, if either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the Resent headers (Resent-Sender, Resent-From, Resent-To, Resent-Cc, and Resent-Bcc), otherwise the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the standard address headers (Sender, From, To, Cc, and Bcc).

member.exception: An unknown type of cryptography context was used.
A certificate could not be found for the signer or one or more of the recipients.
The private key could not be found for the sender.
The public key could not be found for one or more of the recipients.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MimeMessage.SignAndEncrypt(MimeKit.Cryptography.CryptographyContext)
member.summary: Sign and encrypt the message to the sender and all of the recipients using the specified cryptography context and the SHA-1 digest algorithm.

remarks.para: If either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be signed using the Resent-Sender (or first mailbox in the Resent-From) address as the signer address, otherwise the Sender or From address will be used instead.

Likewise, if either of the Resent-Sender or Resent-From headers are set, then the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the Resent headers (Resent-Sender, Resent-From, Resent-To, Resent-Cc, and Resent-Bcc), otherwise the message will be encrypted to all of the addresses specified in the standard address headers (Sender, From, To, Cc, and Bcc).

member.exception: An unknown type of cryptography context was used.
A certificate could not be found for the signer or one or more of the recipients.
The private key could not be found for the sender.
The public key could not be found for one or more of the recipients.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.ContentDuration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the content if available.

remarks.para: The Content-Duration header specifies duration of timed media, such as audio or video, in seconds.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.ContentMd5
member.summary: Gets or sets the md5sum of the content.

remarks.para: The Content-MD5 header specifies the base64-encoded MD5 checksum of the content in its canonical format.
For more information, see rfc1864.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.ContentTransferEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the content transfer encoding.
member.remarks: The Content-Transfer-Encoding header specifies an auxiliary encoding that was applied to the content in order to allow it to pass through mail transport mechanisms (such as SMTP) which may have limitations in the byte ranges that it accepts. For example, many SMTP servers do not accept data outside of the 7-bit ASCII range and so sending binary attachments or even non-English text is not possible without applying an encoding such as base64 or quoted-printable.
member.exception: is not a valid content encoding.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.FileName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the file.

remarks.para: First checks for the "filename" parameter on the Content-Disposition header. If that does not exist, then the "name" parameter on the Content-Type header is used.
When setting the filename, both the "filename" parameter on the Content-Disposition header and the "name" parameter on the Content-Type header are set.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Multipart
member.summary: A multipart MIME entity which may contain a collection of MIME entities.

remarks.para: All multipart MIME entities will have a Content-Type with a media type of "multipart". The most common multipart MIME entity used in email is the "multipart/mixed" entity.
Four (4) initial subtypes were defined in the original MIME specifications: mixed, alternative, digest, and parallel.

The "multipart/mixed" type is a sort of general-purpose container. When used in email, the first entity is typically the "body" of the message while additional entities are most often file attachments.

Speaking of message "bodies", the "multipart/alternative" type is used to offer a list of alternative formats for the main body of the message (usually they will be "text/plain" and "text/html"). These alternatives are in order of increasing faithfulness to the original document (in other words, the last entity will be in a format that, when rendered, will most closely match what the sending client's WYSISYG editor produced).
The "multipart/digest" type will typically contain a digest of MIME messages and is most commonly used by mailing-list software.
The "multipart/parallel" type contains entities that are all meant to be shown (or heard) in parallel.

Another commonly used type is the "multipart/related" type which contains, as one might expect, inter-related MIME parts which typically reference each other via URIs based on the Content-Id and/or Content-Location headers.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MultipartRelated.Root
member.summary: Gets or sets the root document of the multipart/related part and the appropriate Content-Type parameters.

remarks.para: Gets or sets the root document that references the other MIME parts within the multipart/related.

When getting the root document, the "start" parameter of the Content-Type header is used to determine which of the parts is the root. If the "start" parameter does not exist or does not reference any of the child parts, then the first child is assumed to be the root.
When setting the root document MIME part, the Content-Type header of the multipart/related part is also updated with a appropriate "start" and "type" parameters.

member.summary: Checks if the contains a part matching the specified URI.
member.remarks: Determines whether or not the multipart/related entity contains a part matching the specified URI.
member.returns: true if the specified part exists; otherwise false.
member.param: The URI of the MIME part.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MultipartRelated.IndexOf(System.Uri)
member.summary: Gets the index of the part matching the specified URI.

remarks.para: Finds the index of the part matching the specified URI, if it exists.

If the URI scheme is "cid", then matching is performed based on the Content-Id header values, otherwise the Content-Location headers are used. If the provided URI is absolute and a child part's Content-Location is relative, then then the child part's Content-Location URI will be combined with the value of its Content-Base header, if available, otherwise it will be combined with the multipart/related part's Content-Base header in order to produce an absolute URI that can be compared with the provided absolute URI.

member.returns: The index of the part matching the specified URI if found; otherwise -1.
member.param: The URI of the MIME part.

member.name: P:MimeKit.Parameter.EncodingMethod
member.summary: Gets or sets the parameter encoding method to use.

remarks.para: Gets or sets the parameter encoding method to use.

The MIME specifications specify that the proper method for encoding Content-Type and Content-Disposition parameter values is the method described in rfc2231. However, it is common for some older email clients to improperly encode using the method described in rfc2047 instead.
If set to , the encoding method used will default to the value set on the .

member.name: T:MimeKit.ParserOptions
member.summary: Parser options as used by as well as various Parse and TryParse methods in MimeKit.
member.remarks: allows you to change and/or override default parsing options used by methods such as and others.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ParserOptions.Default
member.remarks: If a is not supplied to or other Parse and TryParse methods throughout MimeKit, will be used.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.AddressParserComplianceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the compliance mode that should be used when parsing rfc822 addresses.

remarks.para: In general, you'll probably want this value to be (the default) as it allows maximum interoperability with existing (broken) mail clients and other mail software such as sloppily written perl scripts (aka spambots).

para.alert: Even in mode, the address parser is fairly liberal in what it accepts. Setting it to just makes it try harder to deal with garbage input.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.AllowAddressesWithoutDomain
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the rfc822 address parser should allow addresses without a domain.

remarks.para: In general, you'll probably want this value to be false (the default) as it allows maximum interoperability with existing (broken) mail clients and other mail software such as sloppily written perl scripts (aka spambots) that do not properly quote the name when it contains a comma.

member.value: true if the address parser should allow mailbox addresses without a domain; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.MaxAddressGroupDepth
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum address group depth the parser should accept.

remarks.para: This option exists in order to define the maximum recursive depth of an rfc822 group address that the parser should accept before bailing out with the assumption that the address is maliciously formed. If the value is set too large, then it is possible that a maliciously formed set of recursive group addresses could cause a stack overflow.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.ParameterComplianceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the compliance mode that should be used when parsing Content-Type and Content-Disposition parameters.

remarks.para: In general, you'll probably want this value to be (the default) as it allows maximum interoperability with existing (broken) mail clients and other mail software such as sloppily written perl scripts (aka spambots).

para.alert: Even in mode, the parameter parser is fairly liberal in what it accepts. Setting it to just makes it try harder to deal with garbage input.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.Rfc2047ComplianceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the compliance mode that should be used when decoding rfc2047 encoded words.
member.remarks: In general, you'll probably want this value to be (the default) as it allows maximum interoperability with existing (broken) mail clients and other mail software such as sloppily written perl scripts (aka spambots).

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.RespectContentLength
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Content-Length value should be respected when parsing mbox streams.
member.remarks: For more details about why this may be useful, you can find more information at http://www.jwz.org/doc/content-length.html.
member.value: true if the Content-Length value should be respected; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.CharsetEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the charset encoding to use as a fallback for 8bit headers.
member.remarks:
and
use this charset encoding as a fallback when decoding 8bit text into unicode. The first charset encoding attempted is UTF-8, followed by this charset encoding, before finally falling back to iso-8859-1.

member.name: M:MimeKit.ParserOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: By default, new instances of enable rfc2047 work-arounds (which are needed for maximum interoperability with mail software used in the wild) and do not respect the Content-Length header value.

member.name: M:MimeKit.ParserOptions.Clone
member.remarks: Clones a set of options, allowing you to change a specific option without requiring you to change the original.
member.returns: An identical copy of the current instance.

member.name: F:MimeKit.RfcComplianceMode.Loose
member.summary: Attempt to be much more liberal accepting broken and/or invalid formatting.

member.name: F:MimeKit.RfcComplianceMode.Strict
member.summary: Do not attempt to be overly liberal in accepting broken and/or invalid formatting.

remarks.para: Unless overridden, all textual parts parsed by the , such as text/plain or text/html, will be represented by a .
For more information about text media types, see section 4.1 of rfc2046.

member.name: P:MimeKit.TextPart.IsEnriched
member.summary: Gets whether or not this text part contains enriched text.
member.remarks: Checks whether or not the text part's Content-Type is text/enriched or its predecessor, text/richtext (not to be confused with text/rtf).
member.value: true if the text is enriched; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.TextPart.IsFlowed
member.summary: Gets whether or not this text part contains flowed text.
member.remarks: Checks whether or not the text part's Content-Type is text/plain and has a format parameter with a value of flowed.
member.value: true if the text is flowed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.TextPart.IsHtml
member.summary: Gets whether or not this text part contains HTML.
member.remarks: Checks whether or not the text part's Content-Type is text/html.
member.value: true if the text is html; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.TextPart.IsPlain
member.summary: Gets whether or not this text part contains plain text.
member.remarks: Checks whether or not the text part's Content-Type is text/plain.
member.value: true if the text is html; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MimeKit.TextPart.IsRichText
member.summary: Gets whether or not this text part contains RTF.
member.remarks: Checks whether or not the text part's Content-Type is text/rtf.
member.value: true if the text is RTF; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: If the charset parameter on the is set, it will be used in order to convert the raw content into unicode. If that fails or if the charset parameter is not set, iso-8859-1 will be used instead.
